  <link href="http://www.extremetech.com/deals/198279-et-deals-50-off-turtle-beach-ear-force-dxl1-surround-sound-gaming-headset-more" rel="next" title="ET deals: 50% off Turtle Beach Ear Force DXL1 surround sound gaming headset, more"/>

          #stickybanner,

      <div class="add-nav">
       <ul class="breadcrumbs" id="breadcrumbs">
        <!-- Breadcrumb NavXT 5.1.1 -->
        <li class="home">
         <a href="http://www.extremetech.com" title="Go to ExtremeTech.">
          ExtremeTech
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span typeof="v:Breadcrumb">
          <a class="taxonomy category" href="http://www.extremetech.com/category/extreme" property="v:title" rel="v:url" title="Go to the Extreme category archives.">

        <li class="current_item">
         China is going to mine the Moon for helium-3 fusion fuel
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="twocolumns">
       <div id="content">
        <div class="article">
         <div class="title">
          <h2>
           China is going to mine the Moon for helium-3 fusion fuel
          </h2>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="by vcard">
             By
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/author/jhewitt" rel="author" title="Posts by John Hewitt">
              John Hewitt
             </a>
             on January 26, 2015 at 1:01 pm
            </span>
           </li>
           <li class="comments">
            <a data-disqus-identifier="197784 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=197784" href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/197784-china-is-going-to-mine-the-moon-for-helium-3-fusion-fuel#disqus_thread">
             <span>
              Comment
             </span>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div class="content">
          <span id="intelliTXT" name="intellitxt">
           <img alt="Moon-Mining" class="attachment-full wp-post-image" height="354" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Moon-Mining-640x354.png" width="640"/>
           <div class="photo">
            <div class="box2">
             <h3>
              Share This article
             </h3>
             <div class="addthis_sharing_toolbox">
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            Chinas Change lunar probe dynasty is already having a great year. The Change 3 lunar lander surpassed all expectations last week to emerge from its 14th hibernation while the Change 5-T1 just completed its transfer from the Earth-Moon Lagrange Point 2 into a stable orbit around the Moon. Change 3s main mission was only to take spectrographic and ground penetrating radar measurements, but the Change 5 missions will bring back the first samples containing the actual prize  fusion-ready helium-3.
           </p>
           <p>
            One of the main reasons helium-3 is sought as a fusion fuel is because there are no neutrons generated as a reaction product. The protons that do get generated have charge, and can therefore be safely contained using electromagnetic fields. Early dreamers imagined that Saturn or Jupiter would be the ideal places to try and get their hands on some helium-3, but it now appears that the Chinese have set their sights on the Moon.
           </p>
           <p>
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Mining-the-moon1.jpg">
             <img alt="Mining-the-moon1" class="alignright size-medium wp-image-198255" height="164" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Mining-the-moon1-300x164.jpg" width="300"/>
            </a>
           </p>
           <p>
            Although the Sun dispenses ample amounts of helium-3 wherever it blows, the Earth is largely shielded from this windfall by its own magnetic field. The little we do have is mostly generated by various terrestrial processes like cosmic ray bombardment and even relic sources from leftover nuclear warheads. The Moon, on the other hand, is a far more concentrated depot with
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/173530-chinese-rover-begins-its-journey-to-monetize-the-moon-with-video">
             up to five million tons
            </a>
            conveniently embedded in its top surface layer.
           </p>
           <p>
            If you are thinking that panning the entire surface of the Moon might not be a sound business model, consider that helium-3 would probably not be the only payoff expected. Just as extraction of rare earth metals on our own planet is often piggybacked on a larger iron ore harvest, the Moon would offer a lot in the way of other primary raw materials like, for example, titanium.
           </p>
           <p>
            While the West might justify its own inaction on the helium-3 front in terms of old space treaties or lunar conservation, excuses like this are probably laughable to a country like China who now actually is going and getting their own lunar helium-3. The real hurdles they face are not the bureaucratic red tape or even the logistics of a mass space and mining effort, but rather the physics of helium-3 fusion itself. In other words, is helium-3 necessarily the best way to do fusion?
           </p>
           <p>
            There are a couple of possibilities for helium fusion here. If you can excuse the jargon for a moment, the temperatures required for a 21H (hydrogen) plus 32He (helium) reaction are significantly higher than conventional deuterium-tritium fusion. This process can still result in a few of those pesky neutrons so it may not be ideal. The alternative reaction, fusion of 32He with itself requires even higher temperatures to overcome the double positive charges on each helium. It therefore remains to be seen what is the best path forward in fusion. Other issues like how best to extract the energy once generated also loom. For example, it may be advantageous to directly drive electrical turbomachinery using charged protons without any heat conversion  although the claimed efficiencies of 70% would need to be fully vetted.
           </p>
           <p>
            One thing we do know is that we need more helium-3 now. Our own DHS, for example, had hoped to detect the telltale neutron emissions of plutonium smuggled in shipping containers, but it was stalled for the lack of an affordable helium-3 source in our post-nuclear weapons economy. Getting this precious helium from the Moon will undoubtedly be difficult. The realization that it will take significant manpower  actual boots on the lunar surface  I think for now is inescapable in planning future missions. Mining, even if it is barely subsurface, will always be risky. Robots will have their place for sure, but they can not replace our versatility on the moon if they
            <a href="http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/almost-500-miners-trapped-underground-in-ukraine-after-shelling-hits-power-station-10002856.html">
             cannot even replace men at mines here
            </a>
            .
           </p>
           <p>
           </p>
          </span>
         </div>
         <div class="articles-list">
          <div class="holder">
           <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-45">
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-thumbnails">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'thumbnails-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-thumbnails',
        placement: 'Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-text-links">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'hybrid-text-links-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-text-links',
        placement: 'Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="articles-list">
         <div class="holder">
          <div class="widget column widget_tagswidget" id="tagswidget-2">
           <div class="tags">

              </a>
             </li>

               moon
              </a>
             </li>
             <li id="menu-item-115">

              </a>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="widget column widget_disquswidget" id="disquswidget-3">
           <script type="text/javascript">
            var disqus_developer = 1;
           </script>
           <div class="title">
            <span class="count">
             <a href="#disqus_thread">
              Comment
             </a>
            </span>
            <h3>
             Post a Comment
            </h3>
           </div>
           <div id="disqus_thread">
            <div id="dsq-content">
             <ul id="dsq-comments">
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-376846">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376846">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-376846">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-376846">
                  mortimer zilch
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376846">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376846">
                 <p>
                  The cleanest fusion reaction is that being pursued jointly by PPL and Eric Lerner of
                  <a href="http://www.focusfusion.org" rel="nofollow">
                   http://www.focusfusion.org
                  </a>
                  both in New Jersey. They are using boron gas fuel in microscopic quantity. Boron fusion will produce ONLY electricity. Besides, the real problem with large scale fusion reaction is the instability of the fusion spiking at temperatures for which they have no predicted cause.they are missing something that Dr. Randell Mills calls hydrino reactions in the plasma, and until the big shots recognize this  we will NEVER have a successful large scale tritium reactor.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-376853">

                    Ah, we were chatting yesterday about Mills hydrino reactions I believe. Thx for reading.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I saw this earlier about boron-10 but am not the expert in this: As of 2012, DHS determined the commercial supply of boron-10 would support converting its neutron detection infrastructure to that technology.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>

                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-379120">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-379120">
                         <p>
                          maybe in 5B they can also design a mechanism to do the dumping without getting dumped in the space?
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                     </ul>
                     <!-- .children -->
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-379207">

                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-379768">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-379768">

                        <a href="http://mentalfloss.com/article/52792/there%E2%80%99s-poop-moon" rel="nofollow">

                       </p>

                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-376924">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376924">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-376924">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-376924">
                      eonvee375
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376924">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376924">
                     <p>
                      +1
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-376931">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376931">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-376931">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-376931">
                      Denver Catboy
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376931">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376931">
                     <p>
                      The story of how this came to be is even more interesting than taking dumps on the flags of rivals in space.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Round about 1967, and LBJ is looking at the balance books for the United States. The simple fact is that theres too much going out, not enough coming in, and political realities which are stopping him from raising that number thats coming in (gee, sounds familiar). There were three big drivers of the money leaving the government   domestic welfare programs, the War in Vietnam, and the Space Race. Cutting domestic welfare programs would hurt his chances with the lower-middle class Democrats (note  this was before the Nixon Southern Strategy, so blacks werent exactly a constituency to defend yet). Cutting the Vietnam War was at least Political Suicide, if not flat-out suicide, with the vested interests that were getting fat at the public trough with that. That left the Space Race.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      LBJ had tried everything else, so he tried a desperation measure. He offered up a treaty that no one thought the Russians would ever take  he offered to renounce any claims the US might make on spaceas long as the Russians offered in kind. To everyones surprise, the Russians accepted.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      We had thought the Russians were very close to landing on the moon. The Russians knew that we were very close, and that within the next few years, the US would launch its Saturn V and land on the Moon. What we didnt know at that point is that the brainiac behind the Russian equivalent to the Saturn V, the N1, died in surgery. Their attempts to push the N1 to production without him had beenunfortunate to say the least.  Huge Ka-Boom levels of unfortunate.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      So the Russians saw us basically offering to cede our claim on space, realizing that they had nothing to lose, and promptly signed onto said treaty. Bam. The Space Race had nothing to win anymore. Both the US and the USSR allocated their moneys to other more terrestrial pursuits, and we retreated from the moon. Nixon got in a few years later and put the final nails in the coffin, and that was the end of manned space travel outside of LEO.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      China is technically a signatory of the Outer Space Treaty, but it is obvious that they plan on taking at least parts of the moon for their own purposes. They probably believe that the treaty doesnt extend to mining.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      We will see some very interesting times ahead of us.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-376976">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376976">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-376976">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-376976">
                        Ananarchist
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376976">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376976">
                       <p>
                        More like uneventful, prosperous days, flowing from the nation states death.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>

                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-376945">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376945">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-376945">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-376945">
                      Polecat
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376945">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376945">
                     <p>
                      There is jurisdiction on The Moon..
                      <br/>
                      On July 20, 1969, two American Astronauts landed on the moon
                      <br/>
                      of the planet Earth, in an area known as Mare Tranquilitatis , or Sea of
                      <br/>
                      Tranquility. One of those brave men was Brother Edwin Eugene (Buzz)
                      <br/>
                      Aldrin, Jr., a member of Clear Lake Lodge No. 1417, AF&amp;AM, Seabrook, Texas.
                      <br/>
                      Brother Aldrin carried with him SPECIAL DEPUTATION of then Grand Master J. Guy
                      <br/>
                      Smith, constituting and appointing Brother Aldrin as Special Deputy of the
                      <br/>
                      Grand Master, granting unto him full power in the premises to represent the Grand
                      <br/>
                      Master as such and authorize him to claim Masonic Territorial Jurisdiction for
                      <br/>
                      The Most Worshipful Grand Lodge of Texas, Ancient Free and Accepted Masons, on
                      <br/>
                      The Moon, and directed that he make due return of his acts. Brother Aldrin
                      <br/>
                      certified that the SPECIAL DEPUTATION was carried by him to the Moon on July
                      <br/>
                      20, 1969.
                      <br/>
                      Freemasons claimed it on behalf of all good men of Earth, no flag pooping allowed!
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-377014">

                       </p>

              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-376851">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376851">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-376851">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-376851">
                  havor
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376851">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376851">
                 <p>
                  &gt; but they can not replace our versatility on the moon if they cannot even replace men
                  <br/>
                  &gt; at mines here.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Not saying there not gone be humans needed for the work, but there is a big difference between tunnel mining, and open mining.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Also the cost of using humans on the moon, is much higher then on earth, so the investment in to automated mining equipment is much easier to economical justify.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">

              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-376871">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376871">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-376871">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-376871">
                  Bumblebee Hive
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376871">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376871">
                 <p>
                  I do not think we should mine the moon without proper expertise. The moon could be very brittle and mining it could destroy it. Also removing mass from it could affect its orbit around us. Dangerous stuff.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-376883">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376883">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-376883">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-376883">
                    Marc Guillot
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376883">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376883">
                   <p>
                    The composition of the Moon is the same of Earth (remember that it did split from Earth), there is no chance of destroying it by surface mining it.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Moons mass is at the order of 10^22 kg, so a couple millions of tones transferred wont have any noticeable effect on its orbit. Anyway if this ever starts being a problem, we can upload as much mass as we download (for example sending there our nuclear wastes, ).
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-376928">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376928">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-376928">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-376928">
                      eonvee375
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376928">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376928">
                     <p>
                      you could send up there my trash too,
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      would add couple of millions
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-376934">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376934">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-376934">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-376934">
                      Denver Catboy
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376934">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376934">
                     <p>
                      The current theory about Lunar formation doesnt have the moon splitting from Earth as much as it does having the moon blasted off by an impact between two smaller protoplanets. The prevailing theory is that something Mars-Sized slammed into something Venus Sized and created something Earth-Sized plus something Moon-Sized in a tight orbit. There, of course, are alternative ideas, such as two smaller objects that were nearly equal sized smashing together.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      The idea that Earth spun off the moon by itself is discounted because theres not enough angular momentum in the Earth-Moon system to match that idea.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-376964">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-376964">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-376964">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-376964">
                        Marc Guillot
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376964">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376964">
                       <p>
                        I know, but thanks for remainding it. I didnt want to get into too much detail.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->

               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-376873">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-376873">
                 <p>
                  Russia had their eye on this as well if I recall correctly. Well have to start cloning like Lunar Industries or 3D printing mining robots..
                  <br/>
                  If only we dreamt with as much vision and forethought on our own surfaces endeavours.
                  <br/>
                  In all honesty as much as I like the idea of abundant clean energy, I dont see us getting there soon enough. We need to revamp our societal business model, not hope to merely expand it ecologically. Time will tell.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>

                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-379327">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-379327">

                     <span id="dsq-author-user-379327">
                      ChipsAhoyMcCoy
                     </span>
                    </cite>

                     <p>
                      Unless china has the ability to comunicate with spaceships on the dark side of the moon, an accident (lets just say we use EMP to blow out their electronics) could never be linked to the actions of any particular country and thus there would be no enemy to start a war with.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Lets focus on other technologies like deutrium nuclear fusion and let the generations to come enjoy the moon as its been for millennia instead of having to see a strip mining operation above their heads nearly every night.
                     </p>
                    </div>

                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-379121">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-379121">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-379121">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-379121">
                    h4rm0ny
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-379121">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-379121">
                   <p>
                    We have done this. What you mean is one that is a net energy gain. We have also done this in limited ways. Lockheed Martin believe they have cracked it as well though theyre keeping the details tightly under wraps. And China certainly seem confident enough to invest resource in this. Its coming.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    We really need to get back into the Space race and work on this. It could change everything.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-379182">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-379182">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-379182">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-379182">
                  dc
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-379182">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-379182">
                 <p>
                  but what about the moon men? What about their rights?
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  only western liberals are dumb enough to think that we should worry about disrupting the moon.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-379259">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-379259">

                  Oh no!  Doesnt anyone remember what happened to the moon on Space:1999?
                 </p>

              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-379524">

                 <p>
                  Manifold: Space anybody?
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-379531">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-379531">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-379531">
                 http://moritzfriedrich.com/
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-379531">
                  Mo Friedrich
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-379531">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-379531">
                 <p>
                  I dont know how popular he is outside of Germany, but does anyone know the author Frank Schtzing by chance? He wrote this book called Limit in 2013. Apart from a great story, he outlined the near-future, including space elevators, higher efficiency solar panels, holographic glasses, and among many other accurate predictions the main plot evolves around HE-3 mining on the moon. I think ET readers would have a good read on that one :)
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-379556">

                 </p>

              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-379629">

                  <br/>

                 </p>

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-379861">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-379861">

                 <span id="dsq-author-user-379861">
                  jessstuart
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-379861">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-379861">
                 <p>
                  interesting article, but looks a lot like an article published a couple of weeks ago in The Diplomat: China leads race to Moon: States are quietly preparing to secure fuel for the fourth generation of nuclear weapons, and China is winning.
                  <a href="http://thediplomat.com/2015/01/china-leads-race-to-the-moon/" rel="nofollow">
                   http://thediplomat.com/2015/01/china-leads-race-to-the-moon/
                  </a>
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-379928">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-379928">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-379928">
                 http://www.steroidneedles.net/
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-379928">
                  Frankwhite001
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-379928">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-379928">
                 <p>
                  Has anyone ever thought that if we mine raw materials from other planets and introduce it to earth, it will increase the gravity of earth. Gravity pollution will be the next big thing.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-381913">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-381913">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-381913">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-381913">
                  Frank
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-381913">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-381913">
                 <p>
                  I may be off base here but if mass is removed from the moon would it not affect many different factors on Earth as a whole? Climate, wind patterns, water patterns, rotation, etc?
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
             </ul>

           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var disqus_url = 'http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/197784-china-is-going-to-mine-the-moon-for-helium-3-fusion-fuel';
    var disqus_identifier = '197784 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=197784';
    var disqus_container_id = 'disqus_thread';
    var disqus_domain = 'disqus.com';
    var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
    var disqus_title = "China is going to mine the Moon for helium-3 fusion fuel";
        var disqus_config = function () {
        var config = this; // Access to the config object
        config.language = '';

        /*
           All currently supported events:
            * preData  fires just before we request for initial data
            * preInit - fires after we get initial data but before we load any dependencies
            * onInit  - fires when all dependencies are resolved but before dtpl template is rendered
            * afterRender - fires when template is rendered but before we show it
            * onReady - everything is done
         */

        config.callbacks.preData.push(function() {
            // clear out the container (its filled for SEO/legacy purposes)
            document.getElementById(disqus_container_id).innerHTML = '';
        });
                config.callbacks.onReady.push(function() {
            // sync comments in the background so we don't block the page
            var script = document.createElement('script');
            script.async = true;
            script.src = '?cf_action=sync_comments&amp;post_id=197784';

            var firstScript = document.getElementsByTagName( "script" )[0];
            firstScript.parentNode.insertBefore(script, firstScript);
        });
                    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var DsqLocal = {
        'trackbacks': [
        ],
        'trackback_url': "http:\/\/www.extremetech.com\/extreme\/197784-china-is-going-to-mine-the-moon-for-helium-3-fusion-fuel\/trackback"    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
(function() {
    var dsq = document.createElement('script'); dsq.type = 'text/javascript';
    dsq.async = true;
    dsq.src = '//' + disqus_shortname + '.' + 'disqus.com' + '/embed.js?pname=wordpress&amp;pver=2.74';
    (document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('body')[0]).appendChild(dsq);
})();
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>

      <div class="content">
       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-46">
        <script type="text/javascript">
         window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
    _taboola.push({flush: true});
    
    var __ZDTABEVENT = {
        accountid : "",
        init : function(acct) {
            __ZDTABEVENT.accountid = acct;
            var divs = document.querySelectorAll("div[id^=taboola]"), i=divs.length;
            while (i--) {
                divs[i].addEventListener("click", __ZDTABEVENT.clkevt);
                __ZDTABEVENT.track(divs[i].id, "imp");
            }
        },
        clkevt : function(evt){
            __ZDTABEVENT.track(evt.currentTarget.id, "clk");


        },
        track : function(id,evt) {
            var el = document.getElementById(id);
            var placement = el.getAttribute('data-placement');
            var pagetype = el.getAttribute('data-page-type');
            if(window.ga) window.ga('send', 'event', 'Taboola', pagetype + '-' + placement, evt);
            if(window._gaq) window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'Taboola', pagetype+'-'+placement, evt, undefined, true]);
            if (__ZDDMP) { __ZDDMP.Event({signal:'taboola', pubid: __ZDTABEVENT.accountid, ptype:pagetype, placement:placement, evt:evt});}
        }
    };
    __ZDTABEVENT.init('ziffdavis-network15-extremetech');
        </script>
       </div>

        <script type="text/javascript">
         var _sf_async_config = _sf_async_config || {};
/** CONFIGURATION START **/
&lt;!-- set in head --&gt;
_sf_async_config.sections = 'Extreme'; 
_sf_async_config.authors ='John Hewitt';
/** CONFIGURATION END **/
(function(){
function loadChartbeat()
{ window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime(); var e = document.createElement('script'); e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript'); e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript'); e.setAttribute('src', '//static.chartbeat.com/js/chartbeat.js'); document.body.appendChild(e); }

var oldonload = window.onload;
window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
loadChartbeat : function()
{ oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); }

;
})();
        </script>

        <script type="text/javascript">
         jQuery(document).ready(function() {
  setTimeout(function() {
  if (jQuery("#adsense").height() &lt; 8) { 
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','Blocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'Blocked'); }
  } else {
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','NotBlocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'NotBlocked' ); }
    }
	}, 2000);
});
        </script>

  <script type="text/javascript">
   // &lt;![CDATA[
        var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
        (function () {
            var nodes = document.getElementsByTagName('span');
            for (var i = 0, url; i &lt; nodes.length; i++) {
                if (nodes[i].className.indexOf('dsq-postid') != -1) {
                    nodes[i].parentNode.setAttribute('data-disqus-identifier', nodes[i].getAttribute('rel'));
                    url = nodes[i].parentNode.href.split('#', 1);
                    if (url.length == 1) url = url[0];
                    else url = url[1]
                    nodes[i].parentNode.href = url + '#disqus_thread';
                }
            }
            var s = document.createElement('script'); s.async = true;
            s.type = 'text/javascript';
            s.src = '//' + 'disqus.com/forums/' + disqus_shortname + '/count.js';
            (document.getElementsByTagName('HEAD')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('BODY')[0]).appendChild(s);
        }());
    //]]&gt;
  </script>
